<p>Our project converts A.S.L. (American Sign Language) gestures to speech. To accomplish this task, three kinds of sensors - Flex sensors, Contact Sensors and an accelerometer have been used. </p><p><strong>Working of Flex sensors:</strong></p><p>The flexing (ie. bending) of fingers is detected by measuring the resistance of these resistive devices. They are usually 4.5” or 2.2”. As the curvature of the flex sensor increases, the measured resistance between its terminals increases.</p><p><br><br><img src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/oto7EVp8vQGbSMwHWSSoNfUwrEwJJm34t1Wg0ed9lJmOwf3G-kkOcZyV9UFy7L0ZUPYMJinVWvpJPISjirnCPsn7kAWjftNb5gbgI_vFIdADCALcGxha0I7F6IwYu_Fomsv5DYI" width="225px;" height="225px;" style="border-width: medium; border-style: none; transform: rotate(0rad);"><img src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/DZLi4dO3v9orhYnYyHJwpo2M7M4nAZ5DGFzSNq8G3CmJ3P7LZLEW8QYNfWufc5PX2HqUSMqun4nfroR0AypWR9ppjzhjZrnEr1tOGZHxfr74l1OKiWtYXJcYWc-6c2WSZzY2rh0" width="340px;" height="148px;" style="border-width: medium; border-style: none; transform: rotate(0rad);"></p><p><strong>Working of Contact Sensors:</strong></p><p>As their name implies, these sensors detect whether two parts of the hand are in contact with each other. Each contact sensor consists of two copper plates of which one is grounded and the other is connected to the ATMega 2560 in INPUT PULL UP MODE. When two sensors touch each other, they both are grounded and hence the reading changes from 1 to 0.</p><p><strong>Working of ATMega 2560:</strong></p><p>This is the Micro-controller we used to receive and process the data from the flex and contact sensors. It is an 8 bit microcontroller with features ADC (16 channel), UART(4 RX/TX), etc. For more information refer to the  <a href="http://www.atmel.com/images/doc2549.pdf" target="_blank">ATmega2560 datasheet</a>.</p><p><img src="http://sigma.octopart.com/17561084/image/Atmel-ATMEGA2560-16AU.jpg" style="width: 316px;"></p><p><strong>Bluetooth Module</strong>:</p><p>Bluetooth is a wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances.</p><p>These transfer data byte-by-byte (serially) from the Microcontroller to the Android App.</p><p><img src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/vwI4odyFa6iCLfZsG0cubabIy8eFprb5hfzFWcU3aqukUieViVoFYt66RdIMi0DrpMjurVN7aA5Cv0UF5Jq6l3PZCBQv0-RqIu600yU76q6uQjYlEsQLbSDEAT0XEyTmlrVWvy0" width="225px;" height="225px;" style="border-style: none; border-width: initial; transform: rotate(0rad); -webkit-transform: rotate(0rad);"></p><p><strong>Accelerometer: </strong></p><p>It is a device that measures proper acceleration in three perpendicular directions. Since some letters have similar symbols but differ in the movement of the hand, we needed to incorporate accelerometers in our project.</p><p><img src="http://www.hobbytronics.co.uk/image/cache/data/ht/sensors/adxl335-breakout-500x500.jpg" style="width: 319px;"></p><p><strong>Android App:</strong></p><p>The letter corresponding to the user’s sign is broadcasted to the App. The App adds this letter to its clipboard. Once the user completes his or her sentence, the App spell-checks the sentence and adds spaces between the words. It then converts the text to speech.</p><p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="Image result for android" style="width: 173px;"></p>
